awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Evaluating controls on orogenic structural style by constraining the spatio-temporal evolution of a retroarc thrust belt
awd_abstract_narration:
Though all continental mountain belts form as continental crust is shortened in regions of plate convergence, they exhibit major variations in width, elevation, and types of rocks involved. Given that many of these mountain belts are associated with some of Earth's most significant geological hazards and host prolific petroleum and mineral deposits, there is considerable societal and scientific interest in identifying the main factors responsible for their differences. This research will test a hypothesis that major differences in these mountain belts result from variations in the types and strengths of rocks that are present prior to the beginning of mountain building. This contribution is significant because it is expected to redefine the relative importance of these variations in influencing not only the geometry of mountain belts, but also the mechanisms through which they form. In addition to the scientific contributions of the project, important societal outcomes include workforce development through the education of graduate and undergraduate students in an important science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) discipline. It fosters scientific literacy of the public through outreach efforts aimed at K-12 students that will result in the training and attraction of students to STEM careers. The project supports broadening of underrepresented groups in STEM. The project contributes to STEM educator development for high school teachers in the northern Rocky Mountain region through the implementation of a field-based course for high school science teachers in the northern Rockies. Results of the research will be disseminated through presentations at professional society meetings and peer-reviewed scientific literature. 
 
The principal investigators will construct a structural, sedimentary, and thermochronologic record of the spatial and temporal transition in structural style--"thin-skinned" deformation of primarily sedimentary units or "thick-skinned" deformation of basement units--in east-central Idaho and southwestern Montana and compare it to the timing of "Laramide" flat subduction beneath Wyoming. The central hypothesis to be tested is that the transition in structural style along the proposed transect, which is outside the classic Laramide region, developed as a result of the pre-orogenic stratigraphic architecture of the upper plate. This work will provide a critical test of whether an intrinsic property of the upper plate, rather than a change in plate boundary geodynamics such as flat-slab subduction, can be a dominant mechanism for controlling orogenic structural style. The team will test the central hypothesis using 1) structural and stratigraphic investigations in east-central Idaho and southwestern Montana to constrain the spatial pattern of structural styles and coeval depocenters and 2) thermochronometry of thrust sheets to constrain the timing of exhumation related to thrusting and coeval foreland sedimentation. The research  design includes zircon and apatite uranium-lead and (uranium-thorium)/helium dating, as well as apatite fission track thermochronometry in the context of field-based structural and stratigraphic investigations; these results will be used to build a regional kinematic model to evaluate the hypothesized non-flat-slab control on the spatio-temporal transition in structural style. Results from this work thus have the potential to transform our knowledge of the causal relationship between thin- and thick-skinned portions of continental fold-thrust belts and could warrant reevaluation of the importance of the pre-orogenic upper crustal architecture in affecting the first order geometries of modern and ancient continental mountain belts.

por.por_cntn:
Since the early 20th century, two different styles of deformation have been recognized in foreland basins adjacent to convergent plate margins, namely thick-skinned and thin-skinned.  Thick-skinned deformation results in foreland basins disrupted by basement block uplifts and is found along many ancient and modern orogenic systems. The creation of broken foreland basins has been linked to several causal mechanisms, but despite the widespread occurrence of these features, the cause and progression from an unbroken to a broken foreland basin is still debated. The North American Cordillera in the western United States is commonly separated into two different structural provinces—the Sevier fold-thrust belt and the Laramide foreland belt. The Laramide foreland belt is characterized by thick-skinned deformation that exhumed basement blocks along high-angle reverse faults. Laramide-style deformation has been linked to shallow-angle subduction of an oceanic plateau beneath western North America—in this context, Laramide-style deformation began at ~90 Ma beneath the margin of southern California and propagated to the northeast within a narrow corridor towards South Dakota by ~60 Ma. In contrast, others have attributed low-angle subduction to an increased rate and orthogonality of convergence between North America and the down-going Farallon plate, resulting in shear stress transmitted into the crust and deformation along preexisting heterogeneities. In the context of these models, slab flattening would have accompanied a change in plate motions ~80-85 Ma and the timing and spatial distribution of related deformation would be much broader than in the corridor model. The goal of this project was to construct a structural, sedimentary, and thermochronologic record of the spatial and temporal transition from thin- to thick-skinned shortening in east-central Idaho and southwestern Montana in order to test the validity of these models.

The results of this project have advanced our knowledge by providing a new tectonic and provenance model of an archetypal broken foreland basin that has been modified by basement-cored uplifts. We have developed a linked structural-sedimentologic geologic history for the foreland basin in southwestern Montana that illustrates basement-involved deformation by at least ~88 Ma. These results have implications for scientists working on other broken foreland basins globally, as well as those focused on the Late Cretaceous history of the western U.S. Cordillera, especially the timing of Sevier and Laramide exhumation.  Our data demonstrate that the Laramide-style uplifts in southwestern Montana do not fit the most salient model for that orogeny, namely flat-slab subduction of an oceanic plateau, and Laramide tectonic models need to be reconsidered in this context. Furthermore, the results of this project have added significant new details to North American paleogeographic reconstructions by refining sediment dispersal models, including recently developed representations of middle Cretaceous transcontinental river systems. Our results allow us to expand the already hypothesized existence of an Appalachian-sourced continent-scale fluvial system into southwestern Montana during Albian time. Moreover, we demonstrate interactions between the fluvial system and tectonic elements, whereby the forebulge of the foreland basin system influenced dispersal of sediment derived from the transcontinental fluvial systems within the western interior seaway.

This study has also facilitated a new application for detrital zircon U-Pb geochronology as it applies to acquiring depositional ages of sedimentary strata. We combined sample preparation techniques typically used to separate a type of fossil called conodonts from carbonate rocks to obtain zircon grains from ancient lake-related carbonate strata in southwestern Montana. Geochronologic dating of these zircons demonstrates that airfall zircon grains from volcanic eruptions accumulate in lakes in greater proportions than zircon grains recycled from older sedimentary strata. The volcanic grains provide robust maximum depositional ages that most often approximate the true depositional age of the strata. Lacustrine carbonate is an important component in many types of tectonic basins, and application of detrital zircon U-Pb geochronology holds considerable potential for dating critical chemical and climatic events recorded in their stratigraphy. It could also reveal new information for the persistent question about whether the stratigraphic record is dominated by longer periods of background fine-grained sedimentation versus short-duration coarse-grained events. In tectonically active basins, lacustrine carbonates may be valuable for dating the beginning of tectonic subsidence, especially during periods of finer-grained deposition dominated by mudrocks and carbonates.

As part of the broader impacts of this project, two graduate students from the University of Iowa completed Master’s theses and one graduate student completed a Ph.D. dissertation. Both Master’s students are working in their fields and the Ph.D. student has moved on to a post-doc position. In addition, four undergraduate students were involved in the research.  One of the undergraduate students is currently completing a Master’s degree at another institution. A second undergraduate student is pursuing a Master’s degree at the University of Iowa. The other two students are still working towards obtaining their Bachelor’s degrees.  All students involved traveled to other institutions to participate in lab work and presented their research results at national meetings.
